abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            unsatisfactory, and sustainability is unlikely. Despite a
            modest institutional development impact, both performances
            by the Bank, and Borrower were unsatisfactory. Considering
            the current quality assurance standards, project preparation
            was deficient, with appraisal of works based only on
            preliminary engineering designs, with very narrow remedial
            action, particularly as it regards the underestimated
            project cost increase of approximately seventy three
            percent. Lessons show that the lack of a regulatory
            framework, hindered the possibilities for the Karachi Water
            and Sewerage Board (KWSB) to make full use of the support
            provided by the project in strengthening the institution.
            There was no regulatory action to give KWSB the autonomy to
            exercise changes, neither in private sector involvement,
            tariff adjustments, nor collection enforcement, changes
            which could have improved service quality, in addition to
            providing a sustainable management capacity, to offset
            continued leaks, and prevent inequalities in resource
            allocation. Furthermore, this lack of autonomy translates
            into the financial covenants' limitations to assure
            compliance, thus the usefulness of financial undertakings is
            questioned, in the absence of governance, and adverse
            commercial incentives, obstacles which could have ensured
            the adequacy of water supply.
